etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Thomson. From ancient Greek περιστερά pigeon (perhaps by dissimilation from an unattested *πελιστερά from πελιός livid, dark bluish grey + -τερος, comparative suffix), in allusion to its colour + -ite

definitions: A sodic plagioclase in the albite–oligoclase range of composition with a blue or bluish-white opalescence.
